Controversy Explanation: Students protested the student government's invitation of rapper Big Sean to perform at commencement and asked that the invitation be rescinded, alleging that Big Sean promotes rape culture. The student government did not rescind the invitation, and some students held an alternate event.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person, Appeased Protesters. The university president referred to Urban Congo as "offensive" and to Big Sean’s lyrics as "vile and demeaning.”

Controversy Explanation: Senior college officials postponed a screening of the film, American Sniper, after students complained. The screening was rescheduled for the next week and was coupled with an educational forum that would allow students to "participate in an intellectual discourse about the film and current world events."
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. The college's Vice President for Strategic Communications said: "[T]his decision [to postpone the showing] was made solely by members of the UPAC Cinema Club, after careful consideration of a request by the RPI Muslim Students Association. . . . UPAC has decided that they will show American Sniper during this spring semester, at a date to be announced. The showing will be coupled with an optional educational forum for all members of the Rensselaer campus community to participate in an intellectual discourse about the film and current world events. . . .On behalf of President Shirley Ann Jackson and the Rensselaer administration, we applaud this decision, and this decision-making process. At its core, The New Polytechnic at Rensselaer is guided by societal concerns and ethics."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Mitchell to deliver a commencement speech because of Mitchell's views on abortion. Mitchell spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Nutter to deliver a commencement speech because of Nutter's support for gay marriage, contraception, and abortion. Nutter spoker successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance. The play was performed off campus.
Public Response: Unknown

School: Saint Louis University School of Law
Controversy Explanation: Members of the Black Law Students Association asked the school’s dean to rescind its invitation of McCulloch because of McCulloch's role as the prosecutor in the Ferguson police shooting case. McCulloch spoke successfully after police escorted approximately 12 disruptive protesters from the event.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Matthews to deliver a commencement speech because of Matthews' views on abortion and gay rights. Matthews spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Brooks to deliver a commencement speech because of Brooks' support for gay marriage. Brooks spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to rescind Rauner's invitation to speak at commencement, objecting to Rauner's proposed budget cuts to the university system. Rauner spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Faculty members protested the college's selection of Giuliani to deliver a commencement address, calling Giuliani a "controversial, divisive ideologue" and objecting to Giuliani's comments regarding African American communities and crime. The college refused to disinvite Giuliani and he spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The college president said: "Mr. Giuliani is expected to speak about his role in the Sept. 11 recovery. I believe this will be of interest and value to our students."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Civil Liberties, Gender, Political Views, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: hooks hosted a conversation with Gloria Steinem which became a subject of controversy. A local bishop called on the college to rescind its invitation to Steinem. TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, petitioned the college to cancel Steinem's conversation with hooks because of Steinem's views on abortion, same-sex marriage, feminism, religion, and Marxism (many of which hooks shared). The petition garnered more than 28,000 signatures. hooks spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). "Throughout the week, the social-justice scholar hooks will host a number of talks related to her work on topics including the theology of love and radical hospitality, community building and racial inequality. She and Steinem will participate in a dialogue on April 21. We are not expecting Ms. hooks and Ms. Steinem to be discussing abortion. These two influential figures have conducted such a dialogue four or five times before, and abortion has seldom if ever come up. Rather, they will share their perspectives on the ways roles and opportunities for women have evolved in their lifetimes, and the impact changes have had on the country. Steinem also has spoken a great deal about domestic violence in recent years. Obviously we have a somewhat different view of the question of speakers on a college campus, but we respect the bishop's desire to comment on something he feels so strongly about."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Civil Liberties, Gender, Political Views, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: A local bishop called on the college to rescind its invitation to Steinem and TFP Student action, an off-campus organization, started a petition demanding the college cancel Steinem's conversation with author Gloria Jean Watkins (pen name: bell hooks) because of Steinem's views on abortion, gay marriage, feminism, religion, and Marxism. The petition garnered more than 28,000 signatures, but Steinem spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). "Throughout the week, the social-justice scholar hooks will host a number of talks related to her work on topics including the theology of love and radical hospitality, community building and racial inequality. She and Steinem will participate in a dialogue on April 21. We are not expecting Ms. hooks and Ms. Steinem to be discussing abortion. These two influential figures have conducted such a dialogue four or five times before, and abortion has seldom if ever come up. Rather, they will share their perspectives on the ways roles and opportunities for women have evolved in their lifetimes, and the impact changes have had on the country. Steinem also has spoken a great deal about domestic violence in recent years. Obviously we have a somewhat different view of the question of speakers on a college campus, but we respect the bishop's desire to comment on something he feels so strongly about."

Controversy Explanation: Conservative students argued that university funds shouldn't be used to have Davis speak, claiming much of the student body doesn't respect Davis because of her leftist views. Davis spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). A VP for for Undergraduate Education and Student Affairs published a statement that included: “The caliber of speakers who will be part of our African-American Lecture Series further affirms our commitment to diversity and the profound contributions of African-Americans to our campus, state and country.”

Controversy Explanation: As part of an art project, a graduate student posted signs that said "White Only" and "Black Only" by water fountains and outside bathrooms on campus. Campus police removed the signs and administrators said they would "review this matter through appropriate university policies and procedures."
Public Response: Neutral (disingenuous). We are committed to ensuring that the University at Buffalo is welcoming and supportive of all members of our community. On a daily basis our faculty and students explore sensitive and difficult topics in an environment that values freedom of expression, and this week’s student art project is generating considerable dialogue. The university is encouraging our community to discuss how we negotiate the boundaries of academic freedom in a safe and inclusive environment that values freedom of expression and further builds a culture of inclusion. The University at Buffalo stands strong in our commitment to ensuring that such discourse occurs in a safe, inclusive and intellectually open environment."

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Race, Other
Controversy Explanation: Students chanted and shouted throughout a discussion between Provost Steele (and Chancellor Dirks) on the meaning and value of higher education. The students said that black students suffered hardships, that Dirks' salary was too high, and that the university did not grant tenure to a particular environmental science professor. The chanting and shouting briefly stopped when The Berkeley Forum, the event organizers, announced it would reformat the Q&A period to accommodate all audience members instead of only the handful who had been preselected to ask questions. The event was shut down when the chanting and shouting resumed after Steele (and Dirks) declined to comment on some of the questions.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Student groups denounced the Black Student Union's invitation of Farrakhan to campus and petitioned the university to rescind his invitation, but Farrakhan spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president wrote in an open letter: "[W]e cannot as a society allow what we regard as vile speech to lead us to abandon the cherished value of free speech. . . [we should, however] condemn these merchants of hatred when they come into our community."

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Race, Other
Controversy Explanation: Students chanted and shouted throughout a discussion between Chancellor Dirks (and Provost Steele) on the meaning and value of higher education. The students said that black students suffered hardships, that Dirks' salary was too high, and that the university did not grant tenure to a particular environmental science professor. The chanting and shouting briefly stopped when The Berkeley Forum, the event organizers, announced they would reformat the Q&A period to accommodate all audience members instead of just the handful who had been preselected to ask questions. The event was shut down when the chanting and shouting resumed after Dirks (and Steele) declined to comment on some of the questions.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Some Jewish leaders on campus (and off campus) opposed UCLA’s Alan D. Leve Center for Jewish Studies' invitation of West due to his criticism of Israel and support for the BDS movement. The director of the center refused to rescind the invitation and West spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). The director of the center that invited West, held fast in a statement to reporters:  "[I don't] excuse, justify, or apologize for West’s positions on Israel . . . We may have pressure to rescind the invitation but that’s not the plan. . . . We didn't ask him [West] to come to UCLA to espouse a particular political position or platform—we asked him to talk about Heschel and the relationship to the civil rights movement.”

Controversy Explanation: The university president announced that the university would cover the mural because of its stereotypical depictions of black musicians and Native Americans. In 2016, the university uncovered the mural because it “told a story through a talented artist’s eyes within the context of her time.”
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: A petition called on student group organizers of a screening of the film, American Sniper, to cancel the screening, calling the film "war propaganda guised as art" and saying it "reveals a not-so-discreet Islamophobic, violent, and racist nationalist ideology." After meeting with students who opposed the screening, organizers postponed it, then met with other student groups to arrange a screening along with a discussion panel following the event. The screening took place two weeks later.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. The university president released a statement: SEE, the event organizer,  "is a student-run organization comprised of undergraduate students who work alongside advisers in the creation, promotion and operation of campus events. . . . The university is not involved in the decision-making process to determine which films are brought to campus. . . . I take tremendous pride in the conduct of our students. MSA members were right to speak up for what they believe in. They deserve our admiration, not the scorn and vitriol they got on Facebook. I also applaud the student leaders of SEE for listening to the concerns of their fellow students. Their decision to reschedule the screening so a constructive dialogue could be held marks the exercise of free speech and a sensitivity to campus values of respect and inclusion."

Controversy Explanation: Student groups and students petitioned the university to cancel the a screening of the film, American Sniper, because of its "negative and misleading stereotypes" of Muslims and because it "sympathizes with a mass killer." University administrators canceled the screening. After public outcry, the university rescheduled the event, and it proceeded without incident.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. The university president said: "Though I agree that the initial cancellation was a mistake due to free speech and choice issues it created, I am also very concerned for those who feel marginalized and hurt by certain types of speech. Muslim students on our campus have shared some of their experiences with me in this regard. As a community, we must confront all of these issues in order to provide a safe and free place to learn and interact, and an environment that is conducive to the discussion of controversial topics."

Controversy Explanation: During a speech by Halbertal on assymetrical warfare, students and off-campus groups shouted, making enough noise that Halbertal required about half an hour, and the removal of several protesters, to begin speaking. Protesters objected to Halbertal's views on war crimes and civilian casualties. After about 30 minutes, Halbertal resumed his lecture and completed his remarks.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The dean's official statement included: "As members of a university community, we should welcome -- indeed, insist -- on hearing a wide range of viewpoints, and we should condemn any efforts to silence free speech through protests of the sort that took place at the law school yesterday. . . . [It] is unacceptable that they [the protestors] should seek to deny other students and community members their own opportunity to hear an invited guest speak. Values of free speech and academic freedom are central to the University’s mission; we disregard them at our peril."

Controversy Explanation: Students wrote letters to the student government asking it to cancel a screening of the film, American Sniper, after a student wrote a letter to the editor of the student newspaper describing the movie as dehumanizing to Muslims and said the screening would make her feel unsafe. The screening proceeded as planned.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to disinvite Abbott from delivering a commencement speech because of Abbott's views on immigration and his opposition to same-sex marriage, claiming these views do "not align with the spirit of the University of North Texas." Abbott spoke at commencement after police removed a dozen protesters.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president said: "I don't expect the whole campus to appreciate the points of view of [a speaker] or endorse them . . . But I expect them to listen because creating an informed and educated citizenry and engaging in public dialog and discourse is a healthy thing for our campus."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of then-President Obama to deliver a commencement speech because of Obama's views on abortion and his support for stem-cell research. An online petition created by the Cardinal Newman Society opposed the university's invitation of Obama and garnered almost 65,000 signatures. Obama spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. A university spokesperson said: "I can't foresee that occurring [that the invitation be revoked]. We made an invitation to the president and he's accepted. We expected criticism and it's nothing beyond what we expected."

Controversy Explanation: After an activist organization criticized the film, Honor Diaries, as Islamophobic, the university canceled a screening of the film "because the format and setting did not allow for appropriate discussion following the screening." The university rescheduled the screening for later in the semester during a women's conference.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. In an email the university provost said: "The University of South Dakota supports free speech and robust discussion of controversial topics in a setting that offers respect to all involved. The earlier showing of ‘Honor Diaries’ was cancelled because the format and setting did not allow for appropriate discussion following the screening.  Whenever USD hosts speakers or films that are controversial the goal is to promote education and better understanding of the people and issues involved."

Controversy Explanation: Anti-amnesty activists shouted down Gutierrez's speech because of his views on immigration. Gutierrez left before the scheduled Q&A.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: Venker was invited to attend a student-run, alumni-funded speaking series titled the "Uncomfortable Learning" series. The students who run the series disinvited her because other students objected to her criticism of feminism and felt she used sexist and homophobic stereotypes. When reinvited, Venker declined the invitation.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. A spokesperson for the university made it clear that Venker was disinvited by the students who had asked her to speak in the first place, not by the college. "[Williams has] a history of bringing controversial speakers to campus. . . . We don't shy away from that.  [For example,] We don't cancel commencement speakers."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation to Johnson to deliver a commencement speech, calling Johnson "an outspoken advocate for HIV/AIDS prevention and safe sex." Johnson spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Holder to deliver a commencement speech because of Holder's support for the Affordable Care Act. Holder spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Landrieu to deliver a commencement speech because of Landrieu's views on abortion. Landrieu spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Vice Dean of Harvard's law school, told Teng, a human rights lawyer and fellow at the Harvard Kennedy School, to cancel a discussion he had organized between himself and Chen Guangchen, a fellow Chinese dissident, because the discussion was scheduled a day after Harvard's presiedent was flying back from Beijing after meeting Xi Jingping and holding it would "embarass" Harvard. Teng canceled the event and was asked not to discuss it.
Public Response: Neutral: The Vice Dean of the law school said: "Having for years served on the Scholars at Risk Committee and for decades hosted a broad range of scholars and law related activists from China at HLS, I tried to make Dr. Teng’s time here academically fruitful. I invited him to speak in my class around the time in question, introduced him to colleagues and met with him frequently about his research, his plans, and his family. I did ask that he schedule the event in question after our University President had left Beijing."

Controversy Explanation: Chen was invited to participate in a discussion by Teng Biao, a fellow at the Harvard Kennedy School. Twice before the scheduled evenet, the Vice Dean of Harvard's law school contacted Teng and asked him to cancel the discussion, because it was scheduled a day after Harvard's presiedent was flying back from Beijing after meeting Xi Jingping and holding it would "embarass" Harvard. Teng canceled the event and was asked not to discuss it.
Public Response: Neutral: The Vice Dean of the law school said: "Having for years served on the Scholars at Risk Committee and for decades hosted a broad range of scholars and law related activists from China at HLS, I tried to make Dr. Teng’s time here academically fruitful. I invited him to speak in my class around the time in question, introduced him to colleagues and met with him frequently about his research, his plans, and his family. I did ask that he schedule the event in question after our University President had left Beijing."

Controversy Explanation: The campus chapter of Law Students for Reproductive Justice invited Raclin, the chair of the board of trustees for Planned Parenthood in St. Louis and a former professor at the university, to give a speech on campus. Shortly before the event the university pressured Law Students for Reporoductive Justice to move the event off-campus because Raclin's views on abortion raised  "issues of Catholic moral and ethical teaching." The event was moved off-campus.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous): The vice president of marketing and communications said: "Bob McCulloch speaking at the law school did not raise issues of Catholic moral and ethical teaching, whereas in this case, there's a potential conflict with Catholic teaching. That's the difference between the two."

Controversy Explanation: After a faculty member saw the Assata Shakur mural on the university's Gender and Sexuality Resource Center's Facebook page and criticized it because Shakur, formerly known as Joanne Chesimard, was on the FBI's list of most wanted terrorists for killing a state trooper in New Jersey, and then escaping prison and fleeing to Cuba, administrators decided to have a mural of Shakur painted over because "the mural does not reflect the Guiding Values of Marquette University."
Public Response: Condemned Expression.  In a statement the university said: "This is extremely disappointing as the mural does not reflect the Guiding Values of Marquette University. It is being removed immediately. We are reviewing the circumstances surrounding the mural and will take appropriate action."

Controversy Explanation: A university administrator informed the artist, Cory Oberndorfer, that he would either have to cover the word fucking on his mural or destroy it. Oberndorfer painted over the word with a black rectangle. University administrators later informed Oberndorfer that he could restore his mural to its original state as long as he would cover up the word upon request during special events.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  In an offical statement the university said: "American University will not censor art. The mural, “Bitter/Sweet” by Cory Oberndorfer, currently showing in the center will remain there. The center will work with Mr. Oberndorfer to restore the mural to its original state. However, we hope that the community appreciates our intention to be sensitive and responsible as we display art in a very public space. As much as our goal is to preserve and share the vision of artists, we must also consider the young students, children, parents, and all members of the community who grace our halls throughout the day."

Controversy Explanation: A staff member at the college temporarily blocked access to Essense of Self, an art exhibit featuring images of men and women engaging in homosexual actions with themselves, by posting a sign outide the exhibit that read: "WARNING: MATURE CONTENT ART SHOWING IN PROGRESS." The staff member also locked the doors, and covered the windows and doors to restrict visibility of the exhibit. A faculty member unlocked the door and removed the covers from the artwork.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: After student and faculty complaints, the college president temporarily covered two murals, which depicts a meeting between English colonists and Mohawk tribal members before the 1755 Battle of Lake George, in The Log building on campus after it reopened. He then created a committee to provide a recommendation for how to address the concerns about the murals. A year later the committee recommended that the the college keep the mural but add descriptions contextualizing it. In 2019, the college hung a plaque next to the murals explaining that the mural's artist "“often included racially stereotyped images of Native people" in his artwork. In 2020, a new college president announced that the murals would be removed and "preserved as artifacts for scholarly study."
Public Response: Neutral.  In an email to the campus community the college president said: "The murals, found on the walls of the Log, attracted concern because of the artist’s portrayal of Native Americans and of the relationship between the Mohawks and the British. This fall we’ll relocate the murals and associated fixtures out of the Log to the Library’s Special Collections facility. There, the items can be preserved as artifacts for scholarly study, rather than displayed as decorative objects in our alumni and community gathering-space."

Controversy Explanation: Gil-Li Vardi, an Israeli military historian was invited to speak on campus by Ami Pedhazur, a professor og government at the university and director of the university's Institute for Israeli Studies. During the event, a group of pro-Palestinian activists, including a government doctoral student, disrupted the proceedings, reportedly accusing the speakers of promoting Israeli militarism. Pedahzur and the protesters engaged in a heated exchange, which was partially recorded and posted online. Pedahzur later characterized the protest as an attempt to silence the event and intimidate speakers, likening the disruption to the tactics of violent extremists. The graduate student and his supporters accused Pedahzur of physically intimidating them and filed a discrimination complaint against him. It is not clear that the event resumed.
Public Response: High Honors.  The university's president said: "Free discourse is vital to The University of Texas. As a university committed to knowledge and discovery, UT is steadfast in its support of inquiry and debate. Yet free speech also carries with it responsibility. The expression of free speech is not a license to drown out the speech of others, or to shout down ideas one disagrees with. As the University of Chicago states in its 'Principles of Free Expression,' a university 'has a solemn responsibility not only to promote a lively and fearless freedom of debate and deliberation, but also to protect that freedom when others attempt to restrict it.' In this spirit, I appreciate Professor Pedahzur’s work to foster debate and protect freedom of speech for all, including the diverse students he teaches and the visiting scholars he hosts on campus."

Controversy Explanation: Pedahzur, a professor of government at the university and the director of the university's Institute for Israel Studies, hosted and moderated a talk by Gil-Li Vardi, an Israeli military historian. During the event, a group of pro-Palestinian activists, including a government doctoral student, disrupted the proceedings, reportedly accusing the speakers of promoting Israeli militarism. Pedahzur and the protesters engaged in a heated exchange, which was partially recorded and posted online. Pedahzur later characterized the protest as an attempt to silence the event and intimidate speakers, likening the disruption to the tactics of violent extremists. The graduate student and his supporters accused Pedahzur of physically intimidating them and filed a discrimination complaint against him. It is not clear that the event resumed.
Public Response: High Honors.  The university's president said: "Free discourse is vital to The University of Texas. As a university committed to knowledge and discovery, UT is steadfast in its support of inquiry and debate. Yet free speech also carries with it responsibility. The expression of free speech is not a license to drown out the speech of others, or to shout down ideas one disagrees with. As the University of Chicago states in its 'Principles of Free Expression,' a university 'has a solemn responsibility not only to promote a lively and fearless freedom of debate and deliberation, but also to protect that freedom when others attempt to restrict it.' In this spirit, I appreciate Professor Pedahzur’s work to foster debate and protect freedom of speech for all, including the diverse students he teaches and the visiting scholars he hosts on campus."

Controversy Explanation: Nomani, a journalist and activist known for advocating Islamic feminism and criticizing Islamic extremism, was invited to speak at Duke’s Muslim Students Association (MSA) event as part of the university’s "Islamic Awareness Month." Five days before her scheduled talk, the Duke University Center for Activities and Events canceled her appearance following an email from the president of Duke’s Muslim Students Association (MSA) to Muslim students and faculty objections. The email from the MSA criticized Nomani’s views, accused her of having a "nefarious alliance" with so-called Islamophobic speakers, like Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Bill Maher, and cited Omid Safi’s (a professor of Islam at the university) condemnation of her. After Nomani challenged the cancellation and requested evidence against her, the university reversed the decision and reinstated her invitation. Nomani spoke successfully on campus.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  A university spokesperson stated: "Duke is strongly committed to free expression and open discussion of controversial issues... We regret that there was a misunderstanding among our students and staff that made it seem like Ms. Nomani was no longer invited to speak at Duke. Once we became aware of it, Duke immediately let Ms. Nomani know that she was welcomed to speak with our students and the larger community, which she did."

Controversy Explanation: Students protested a campus speech featuring Murray because of Murray's views on race, claiming that the invitation hurt students of color. The university postponed the event indefinitely.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous), Appeased Protesters, Encouraged (Approved of) Self-Censorship. Murray published comments from the university president to Murray's employer in an open letter to university students: "Given the lateness of the semester and the full record of Dr. Murray’s scholarship, I realized we needed more time to prepare for a visit and postponed Wednesday’s conversation. We want to host robust discussions. We have a long history of being in the middle of conversations that matter, but those take time and careful planning."

Controversy Explanation: Some students opposed the selection of Richards as commencement speaker because of Richards' pro-choice positions as president of Planned Parenthood, claiming that Barnard, by inviting Richards to deliver a commencement speech, conveyed the message that students with other views do not matter. Richards spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person.  The university president said: "Richards is a nationally respected leader in the field of women’s health and reproductive rights, and her unwavering dedication in the fight for access and education is a true inspiration.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and directly contacted the university to confirm that the performance was scheduled and ask that it be canceled. The event took place.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the law school to rescind its invitation of Malloy because of Malloy's views on abortion and support for gay marriage. Malloy spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Kerry to deliver a commencement speech because of Kerry's views on abortion and his support for gay marriage. Kerry spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: Members of the Brandeis community protested and some circulated a petition opposing the university's invitation of Hirsi Ali to deliver a commencement speech, claiming Hirsi Ali's views were anti-Islam. Brandeis rescinded its invitation of Hirsi Ali, claiming it had not previously been aware of her views.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. An official university statement said: "We cannot overlook certain of her past statements that are inconsistent with Brandeis University's core values."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Benjamin to deliver a commencement speech because of Benjamin's views on abortion. Benjamin spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown
